Abstract
The elevation of energy density is the constant pursuit for Lithium-ion battery industry. LiNiO2
reacquires recognition because of its high capacity without raising the cut-off voltages. To address the flaws of this kind of cathodes, trace nano-TiO2 modified LiNiO2 is synthesized via a simple solid-state method. Combined with the characterizations, the Ti element is verified to dope into the bulk lattice and locate in the transition-metal sites. After Ti doping, the Ni2+ content is visibly increased due to charge balance, followed by the elevated degree of Li/Ni disorder. The doped Ti and as-generated Ni pillar jointly help to stabilize the material structure and benefit the Li+ de/insertion. The nanosized TiO2 participating in the calcination process can effectively homogenize the size of primary particle, adjust the surface morphology and reduce the specific surface area of material. This morphological regulation may be in favor of reducing the contact area with electrolyte and establishing a stable electrode/electrolyte interface, where some detrimental side-reactions take place. As to electrochemical properties, Ti doping can decrease the electrode polarization, lower the impedance and promote the Li+ transfer. As a result, the Ti-modified LiNiO2 cathodes present enhanced electrochemical performances, especially for the 0.2% Ti-doped (Ti-2) material.
Keywords: Energy conversion; Li-ion batteries; Nanoparticles; Primary particle regulation; Structure stability

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The massive fossil-energy consumption gives rise to the unparalleled global energy crisis and
rigorous environmental issue. In pursuit of sustainable clean energy and high-efficiency energy storage devices, researchers have made a lot of efforts and attempts.1–3 As one of the most reliable methods in electrochemical energy storage, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have gained unprecedented attention and development. With the successful application in electric vehicles (EVs) and hybridelectric vehicles (HEVs), the requirement of higher energy density appears increasingly urgent.4–6 Compared to the development process of anode materials, elevating the specific capacity of cathode materials is the choke point that limits the further blossom of energy density for LIBs.7 Among the various positive materials, Ni-rich materials (LiNixCoyMn1-x-yO2, NCM or LiNixCoyAl1-x-yO2, NCA) derived from LiNiO2 with layered structure seem to be one of the effective solutions. Because the increase of Ni fraction will not only reduce the toxic cobalt element, but also promote the specific discharge capacity.2,8 To date, there are numerous reports that the percentage of Ni has been raised to over 90%, which is close to the extreme end (pure phase LiNiO2) of this Ni-enrichment strategy.9– 11 Another path for pushing the limit of energy density is to raise the charging potential up to 4.5 V or higher. However, problems come one after another, such as inevitable electrolyte decomposition and grievous side reactions induced by metastable Ni4+ at highly delithiated state.12,13 Fortunately, there is no need to worry for LiNiO2, which can deliver a competitive capacity over 220 mAh g–1 at only 4.2 V.14 Therefore, deeper investigation into LiNiO2 materials is meaningful, referential and driving for the optimization and application of all the Ni-rich cathodes.
Despite the advantage of high capacity, LiNiO2-based cathodes have some intrinsic issues to
be addressed, for example, cation disorder, structure instability, multiple phase transition and rock

salt formation.8,15,16 Atom doping is one of the major approaches to conquer the critical drawbacks of Ni-based cathode materials and to enhance their electrochemical behaviors.5,17 Various cation and anion doping strategies have been explored over the past few years, including but not limited W,7 Mo,12 Ti,15,18,19 V,20,21 Zr,2,22 Nb23 and F24. Generally, doping strategy is realized through either a co-precipitation method or a solid-phase diffusion, whereas the latter is believed to be easily operable and cost efficient, especially in industrial application. However, the calcination temperature of LiNiO2 is much lower than the conventional ternary cathode materials because of the decomposition of LiNiO2 over 720 °C,25 which reduces the driving force of the high-temperature solid-phase diffusion process. Thankfully, with the exploration in nanotechnology, researchers gradually approach the critical role of nanomaterials in synthesizing and modifying cathode materials of LIBs26. For instance, Zhang et al21 reported the modified LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 materials using nanosized NH4VO3. It demonstrated that the nanoparticles could easily diffuse into the bulk lattice at a relatively lower sintering temperature. It provides afflatus for doping LiNiO2 by solidphase method. Even so, there are still many unknowns or uncertainties to be figured out in the field of nanoscale modification, such as mechanisms, morphological changes and so on.
Taking all the above factors into account, in this paper, a series of Ti-doped LiNiO2 materials
were synthesized by a simple one-step solid-phase method using nanosized TiO2 as modifying agent. The influence of titanium doping on the structure, surface chemical state, morphology and the electrochemical performance of the materials were investigated in detail. Coupled with different characterizations, it demonstrated that Ti element diffused into the material lattice and made the crystal structure more stable. The resultant expansion of interlayer spacing and generation of more Ni2+ as a pillar effect were beneficial for Li+ transportation. Meanwhile, the participated nano-TiO2

sections.heading: 2.1 Sample preparation
sections.text:
The bare and Ti-modified LiNiO2 cathode materials were synthesized via a simple high-
temperature solid-state method. As raw materials for calcination, a certain amount of nanosized TiO2 (Aladdin Industrial Corporation, China), LiOH·H2O micro powder (Ganfeng Lithium Co., Ltd., China) and spherical Ni(OH)2 precursor (Jinchuan Group Co., Ltd., China) were weighed and blended according to the Li/Me (Me = Ni + Ti) molar ratio of 1.03. The trace dosage of nanosized TiO2 was based on the chemical formula of LiNi1-xTixO2, where the samples with x values of 0, 0.001, 0.002 and 0.004 were denoted as Ti-0, Ti-1, Ti-2 and Ti-4, respectively. After being thoroughly mixed, the raw material was calcined at 550 °C for 5 h and then 690 °C for 12 h under

Powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD; TTR-III, Rigaku) with Cu Kα radiation was utilized to
identify the crystal structures and phase information of the prepared samples. The data were collected in the 2-theta range of 10–80° with a scanning speed of 3° min–1. Rietveld refinement was conducted via the GSAS/EXPGUI program to refine the cell parameters.7 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM; JSM-6360LV, JOEL) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM; Tecnai G2 F20, FEI) were employed to observe the morphologies and micro-structures of the obtained samples. Field emission electron probe microanalyzer coupled with wavelength dispersive spectrometer (FE-EPMA/WDS; JXA-8350F, JOEL) was conducted on cross-section of the material particle to gain the element distribution information. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; ESCALAB 250XI, Thermo Fisher Scientific) and soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy (sXAS) were carried out to obtain the state of relative elements. Soft-XAS measurement was performed at the beam line BL02B of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF, China). Soft-XAS spectra were collected by total electron yield (TEY) mode to obtain information below ~10 nm from the sample surface. Specific surface area was measured by BET method using gas sorption surface area and pore size analyzer (Quadrasorb evo, Quantachrome Instruments). 2.3 Electrochemical measurement

sections.heading: 3.1 Structural changes after Ti modification
sections.text:
The crystal structures and phase compositions of the pristine and Ti-modified materials were
determined by X-ray diffraction, with results shown in Fig. 2. The XRD patterns are indexed to a hexagonal α-NaFeO2 structure with the space group of R m. The sharp and narrow diffraction peaks — 3 indicate their excellent crystallinity.12 No obvious diffractogram of impurity phase is detected because of the trace amount of Ti introduction and/or a well diffusion of Ti atoms into the bulk lattice.7,14 The distinctly divided (006)/(102) and (108)/(110) doublets (magnified in Fig. 2 zones i and ii) also demonstrate a highly-ordered layer structure.25 With careful inspection to the diffraction strongest (003) peak, a slight peak shift to a lower 2-theta value after Ti introduction is detected.

The results demonstrate the introduction of Ti induces the structure changes, similarly to the previous studies.23,27–29 Further determined by the Bragg’s Law, the interplanar spacing is expanded, indicating that Ti atoms successfully diffuse into the crystal lattice of LiNiO2 materials on account of the larger ion radius of Ti4+ (0.605 Å) than that (0.56 Å) of Ni3+.30 To further investigate the structure changes and the occupations of Ti atoms after modification, Rietveld refinements were performed, supposing Ti4+ in 3b site and partial Ni2+ in Li layers. The results were depicted in Fig.S1 and summarized in Table 1, where the low R values indicate the credibility of the refinement. Mild extensions in a, c axes and cell volume are observed with the increasing content of Ti, which is consistent with the inference of the above-mentioned peak shift. The c/a values for all the samples are more than 4.93, indicating that the well-ordered layer structure is not disturbed or destroyed by trace Ti doping. Another notable parameter is the degree of Li/Ni disordering. Apparently, the ratio of Ni in Li site is elevated along with the increase of Ti dosage. This phenomenon is attributed to the charge balance, where the Ti4+ doping into the transition-metal layer leads to partial reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+. Due to the similar ionic radii of Ni2+ and Li+, more generated Ni2+ ions migrate and occupy the Li site to form the ‘Ni2+ pillar’, which is conductive to stabilizing the material structure and suppressing the aggravation of Li/Ni mixing upon continuous charging and discharging process.31,32 This phenomenon of Ni2+ increase is in accordance with many as-reported explanations of high-valent element doping strategy.9,15,21 From another aspect, the higher Ni2+ content is also the booster for the expansion of lattice parameters because its larger ionic radii than Ni3+. The above evidences all point to the Ti atoms’ successfully doping into the bulk lattice of LiNiO2 material.

In Fig. 5(a), a rough surface composed with granular primary particles, with average size of 300– 500 nm, can be observed from the pristine LiNiO2. The larger-sized and angular primary particles may lead to the increase of porosity and surface area, further provide more contact area with electrolyte. As shown in Figs. 5(b)~(d), the introduced nano-TiO2 successfully suppress the size growth of primary particles, which makes the stack of primary particles denser and the surface of secondary particles smoother. For example, the rough primary particle size of Ti-2 is reduced to 150–300 nm. Besides, the edges of primary particles also become more mellow. Consequently, the surface of particle changes to be smoother with less bulky grains and pores, indicating that the nanoTiO2 introduced in the calcination process has a function on adjusting the surface morphology of LiNiO2 particle. Furthermore, the specific surface areas of Ti-0 and Ti-2 samples are around 0.4 and 0.3 m2 g–1. It also demonstrates the Ti-modified materials have a trend in BET surface area reduction, which may relate to the addition of nano-TiO2 for homogenizing the size of primary particles. As known that the severe side-reactions usually take place at the electrode/electrolyte interface, the reduced specific surface area of material particle after nano-TiO2 modification might be more or less beneficial to the suppression of side-reactions and resistance, leading to the promotion of electrochemical performances during cycling.37,38

sections.heading: 3.3 Electrochemical performances
sections.text:
To confirm the influences from the consolidated structure and regulated morphology after Ti
modification, the electrochemical properties of all the samples were tested. The cyclic test was performed at 1 C rate between 3.0 V and 4.2 V after being activated at 0.1 C and 0.5 C for one cycle each. As shown in Fig. 7(a), all samples present similar and typical charge/discharge curves of LiNiO2 without distinct differences, indicating that the trace Ti doping does not affect the electrochemical behaviors of the materials. The pristine one (Ti-0) possesses the largest initial discharge capacity of around 228 mAh g–1 at 0.1 C, and the initial discharge capacities of Timodified materials decrease with an increase in Ti dopant content. Like many works about element doping reported, this phenomenon could be attributed to the migration of more generated Ni2+ into Li layer after being doped with Ti4+.7,9,23 Interestingly, the first-cycle discharge capacities of Ti-1 and Ti-2 sample at 1 C are a bit larger than the pristine one, implying that the enhanced crystal structure by Ti doping may contribute to the stable Li+ transfer at heavier current densities and result in less capacity loss. Fig. 7(b) and Table S1 provide the cycling performances and specific data. All the Ti-modified samples prevail after 50 cycles at 1 C, especially the Ti-2 sample, whose discharge capacity is around 175 mAh g–1 with 85.2% retention. In contrast, the Ti-0 samples yields about 155 mAh g–1, 20 mAh g–1 less than Ti-2, with only 76.4% retention. At higher current densities, the Ti-1 and Ti-2 materials exhibit better rate performances, as depicted in Fig. 7(c). Although the discharge capacities of the two samples are close under 0.5–4 C due to their relatively close doping content, the disparity is obvious when the current density is up to 8 C. Moreover, the relative capacity retention as a function of C-rate for the as-obtained materials are plotted in Fig. 7(d), the Ti-doped materials possess better retention rate at higher rates, especially the Ti-2 sample at 8 C.

sections.heading: 3.4 Mechanisms
sections.text:
CV and EIS measurements were conducted to understand the electrochemical mechanisms
after Ti modification. As shown in Fig. S4(a-b), both Ti-0 and Ti-2 samples present similar CV curves. By contrast, the average potential of Ti-2 reduces to around 3.8 V from 3.9 V. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, the Ti-doped LiNiO2 materials (LiNi1-xTixO2, x = 0.001, 0.002 and 0.004) were
synthesized via a one-step solid-state method using trace nano-TiO2 as modifying agent. At a relatively lower calcination temperature (690 °C), the nano-sized Ti dopant shows a prominent advantage of solid-phase diffusion. FE-EMPA/WDS, XPS and XAS results show that the Ti element by and large diffuses into the particle and exists in the state of tetravalence. XRD analysis demonstrates the increase of Li/Ni disorder, the promotion of Ni2+ pillars and the augmented lattice parameters after Ti4+ doping, which could be beneficial for the structure stabilization and Li+ ion de/insertion. HR-TEM confirms that there is no excess TiO2 adhering on the particle surface like a

SEM and BET results prove that the participated nano-TiO2 has a function of tuning the morphology of particles, which would provide a reduced contact area with electrolyte thus alleviate side reactions and impedance growth. Under the combined action of the above factors, the Ti-modified LiNiO2 materials exhibit significantly improved electrochemical performances. Especially, the Ti-2 sample delivers 175.3 mAh g–1 after 50 cycles at 1 C between 3.0 and 4.2 V, holding 85.2% retention, which exceeds the pristine one by 20.8 mAh g–1 in discharge capacity and 8.8% in retention. Even at 8 C rate, the Ti-2 sample also outshine others. This modification will not only widen and enrich the researches of the LiNiO2 materials, but also be referential for commercial application of all the Ni-rich cathode materials.

metadata.abstractText: The elevation of energy density is the constant pursuit for Lithium-ion battery industry. LiNiO2 reacquires recognition because of its high capacity without raising the cut-off voltages. To address the flaws of this kind of cathodes, trace nano-TiO2 modified LiNiO2 is synthesized via a simple solid-state method. Combined with the characterizations, the Ti element is verified to dope into the bulk lattice and locate in the transition-metal sites. After Ti doping, the Ni2+ content is visibly increased due to charge balance, followed by the elevated degree of Li/Ni disorder. The doped Ti and as-generated Ni pillar jointly help to stabilize the material structure and benefit the Li+ de/insertion. The nanosized TiO2 participating in the calcination process can effectively homogenize the size of primary particle, adjust the surface morphology and reduce the specific surface area of material. This morphological regulation may be in favor of reducing the contact area with electrolyte and establishing a stable electrode/electrolyte interface, where some detrimental side-reactions take place. As to electrochemical properties, Ti doping can decrease the electrode polarization, lower the impedance and promote the Li+ transfer. As a result, the Ti-modified LiNiO2 cathodes present enhanced electrochemical performances, especially for the 0.2% Ti-doped (Ti-2) material.
